quizzes.title: Git and Version Control Fundamentals
quizzes.description: Test your knowledge of Git commands, branching strategies, and version control concepts.

questions.questionText: Which Git command is used to record changes to the repository?
questions.explanation: The `git commit` command records changes to the repository with a descriptive message. `git add` stages changes, `git push` uploads changes to a remote, and `git merge` combines branches.

questions.questionText: What is the primary purpose of a Git branch?

options.text: To save a snapshot of the repository
To create an isolated line of development
To upload changes to a remote server
To view the history of commits

questions.explanation: A Git branch creates a separate line of development, allowing team members to work on new features or bug fixes without affecting the main codebase.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is NOT a valid Git branching strategy?
questions.explanation: Waterfall Branching is not a recognized Git branching strategy. GitFlow, GitHub Flow, and Trunk-Based Development are common and effective strategies.

questions.questionText: What does the `git pull` command do?

options.text: Fetches changes from the remote repository
Merges changes from the remote repository into the current branch
Both fetches and merges changes from the remote repository
Uploads local changes to the remote repository

questions.explanation: `git pull` is a convenience command that fetches changes from a remote repository and then immediately merges them into the current branch.

questions.questionText: How can you undo the last commit while keeping the changes in your working directory?
questions.explanation: `git reset HEAD~1` (soft reset) moves the HEAD pointer back one commit but keeps the changes in the staging area and working directory. `git reset --hard` discards changes, and `git revert` creates a new commit to undo previous changes.

quizzes.title: Docker Containerization Basics
quizzes.description: Explore the fundamentals of Docker, including images, containers, volumes, and networking.

options.text: A running instance of a Docker container
A lightweight, standalone, executable package of software that includes everything needed to run it
A virtual machine for running applications
A network interface for Docker containers

questions.explanation: A Docker image is a read-only template with instructions for creating a Docker container, packing all dependencies (code, runtime, system tools, libraries, etc.).

questions.questionText: Which command is used to list all running Docker containers?
questions.explanation: `docker ps` displays a list of all currently running containers. To see all containers (including stopped ones), use `docker ps -a`.

questions.questionText: How can you ensure data persistence for a Docker container?

options.text: By using `docker commit` to save the container state
By mounting a Docker volume or bind mount
Data is always persistent by default

questions.explanation: Docker volumes and bind mounts are the preferred ways to persist data generated by and used by Docker containers, ensuring data is not lost when a container is removed or recreated.

questions.questionText: Which file is used to define a Docker image's build instructions?
questions.explanation: A Dockerfile is a text file that contains all the commands a user could call on the command line to assemble an image. `docker-compose.yml` is for multi-container applications.

questions.questionText: What is the default network driver for a Docker container if not specified?
questions.explanation: The `bridge` network driver is the default. Containers on the same bridge network can communicate, and isolated containers on different bridge networks cannot. It provides good isolation and basic networking.
